attachments.text: I am trying to get this working on my system, and it appears as though JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER is not reliably set. In my wrapper, the first thing I do is printenv > /Users/darsnack/julialog. Sometimes, the log is full of environment variables, and it is clear that the process is being launch under my user with my full shell environment + rc (zsh). Notably, JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER is unset, and things try to launch in a new terminal window with failed results. Other times, the log is only a few lines ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: External Julia REPL in VSCode

elements.text: Any insight on

messages.text: well, we do start processes that aren't the repl process without JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER set

elements.text: well, we do start processes that aren't the repl process without JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER set

messages.text: did you make sure to forward all arguments etc?

elements.text: did you make sure to forward all arguments etc?

messages.text:
I believe so. Here is what the wrapper script that I set the extension’s executable path to:
```#!/bin/bash

# Wrapper script for launching an external Julia REPL in
# VSCode using the Julia extension.

## Path to julia executable
JULIA=/usr/local/bin/julia
printenv > /Users/darsnack/julialog
if [[ -z ${JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER+1} ]]; then
    ## User-process; launch a new terminal window and exec julia
    cmd="${JULIA} $@"
    exec /Users/darsnack/iterm $cmd
else
    ## Language server process; exec julia
    exec ${JULIA} "$@"
fi```

elements.text: I believe so. Here is what the wrapper script that I set the extension’s executable path to:

#!/bin/bash

# Wrapper script for launching an external Julia REPL in
# VSCode using the Julia extension.

## Path to julia executable
JULIA=/usr/local/bin/julia
printenv > /Users/darsnack/julialog
if [[ -z ${JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER+1} ]]; then
    ## User-process; launch a new terminal window and exec julia
    cmd="${JULIA} $@"
    exec /Users/darsnack/iterm $cmd
else
    ## Language server process; exec julia
    exec ${JULIA} "$@"
fi

messages.text:
I did not quite understand your problem but are you sure the quoting is correct  in `exec /Users/darsnack/iterm $cmd`?
In any case, you can't really rely on things like env vars set in bash/zsh rc files. Those are only inherited by vs code if it was started from sush a shell.

elements.text: I did not quite understand your problem but are you sure the quoting is correct  in
exec /Users/darsnack/iterm $cmd

?
In any case, you can't really rely on things like env vars set in bash/zsh rc files. Those are only inherited by vs code if it was started from sush a shell.

messages.text: Yeah I might be missing quotes around `$@` in `$cmd`, but that’s the case where its a user launched REPL right? Currently, that’s working fine. The issue is that when I open a new VS Code window with a Julia project, I don’t hit the `else` case cause `JULIA_LANGUAGESERVER` is not set (even though it is clear from the commands that this is the language server process trying to start).

messages.text: Hey everybody. Does anyone know how to adjust the colors of the in-editor code execution results? I'm wondering if dimming them might help.

messages.text:
Thanks, these were exactly what I was looking for! :smiley:

I don't know if I can make suggestions that work for everyone, since I'm sure our priorities vary. (I'm looking for visual unobtrusiveness; others probably want high-contrast and readability.) If I find something that might work more broadly (maybe a few adjustable settings that hook into the surrounding background, text and comment colors?) I'll be sure to report back.

elements.text: Thanks, these were exactly what I was looking for!

I don't know if I can make suggestions that work for everyone, since I'm sure our priorities vary. (I'm looking for visual unobtrusiveness; others probably want high-contrast and readability.) If I find something that might work more broadly (maybe a few adjustable settings that hook into the surrounding background, text and comment colors?) I'll be sure to report back.

messages.text: Thanks! There are a bunch of colours defined by themes (<https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/theme-color>), but I haven't found one I was happy with for all themes. Worst case we could just add an opacity setting (or even a colour picker/text box) to configure this. Hasn't been a particularly high priority though.

messages.text: I actually wanted to reach out to them this semester and see how we can in general make sure the integration of Julia in that new extension is good.

elements.text: I actually wanted to reach out to them this semester and see how we can in general make sure the integration of Julia in that new extension is good.

messages.text: For sure.  I think that the brittle solution might mean that if we give them a simple string then the inspector will "just work".  These guys have been very responsive on the jupyter + julia stuff.  Rich especially.  So I think that trying things out and submitting bug reports where there are issues is the way to go.  Rich told me to avoid the insiders version of the notebook interface for now, though, since it has bugs.  I think that if Julia works well with the old notebook then it should work as soon as the new stuff is stable.

messages.text: So if we can somehow fix their regex based thing, I think we should do it. My guess is that would have to happen in the Jupyter extension entirely. I think the mid term solution, though, should be that our existing workspace stuff works for Jupyter Julia kernels. It is _much_ richer than anything could ever be that is based on regex, I believe.

elements.text: So if we can somehow fix their regex based thing, I think we should do it. My guess is that would have to happen in the Jupyter extension entirely. I think the mid term solution, though, should be that our existing workspace stuff works for Jupyter Julia kernels. It is
much
richer than anything could ever be that is based on regex, I believe.

messages.text: In my ideal world we would head towards the following architecture: if the Julia VS Code extension is installed, then the Jupyter extension will use some direct interface with the Julia extension to start kernels, integrate with our existing debugger support, use our workspace stuff and all the other things we have created in the extension. If the Julia VS Code extension is _not_ installed, only then would it fall back to the normal Jupyter ZMQ based communication protocol.

elements.text: In my ideal world we would head towards the following architecture: if the Julia VS Code extension is installed, then the Jupyter extension will use some direct interface with the Julia extension to start kernels, integrate with our existing debugger support, use our workspace stuff and all the other things we have created in the extension. If the Julia VS Code extension is
not
installed, only then would it fall back to the normal Jupyter ZMQ based communication protocol.

messages.text: So essentially I have a two tiered system in mind: when the Julia extension is present, more things work better, but everything also just works if the Julia extension is not installed, but maybe not as fancy and nice.

elements.text: So essentially I have a two tiered system in mind: when the Julia extension is present, more things work better, but everything also just works if the Julia extension is not installed, but maybe not as fancy and nice.

messages.text: Btw. I saw that JupyterLab 3.0 shipped, with debugger support... So we could probably try to integrate the debugger into IJulia.jl now. Fun new project :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Btw. I saw that JupyterLab 3.0 shipped, with debugger support... So we could probably try to integrate the debugger into IJulia.jl now. Fun new project

messages.text: A lot here depends on how the MS folks want to handle more complicated scenarios in the Jupyter extension, for example how they plan to integrate debugger support etc.

elements.text: A lot here depends on how the MS folks want to handle more complicated scenarios in the Jupyter extension, for example how they plan to integrate debugger support etc.

messages.text:
<@U68UUUFPS> I think I agree with this, though a lot is out of our hands.   Your medium-term sure sounds great, but maybe there is some low hanging fruit.

As far as I understand the current situation:
• The inspector thing is just something that is setup through the json for the jupyter extension... or at least that is the hope.  It then replaces the current <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/main/package.json#L1643-L1647>  
• They think it may have used to work, but after julia stopped supporting `whos`  it needed to be fixed.  I think my solution is a good start already in <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/issues/1851#issue-783653844> and might be enough to go talk to them
• I think that the typescript code that uses this stuff might be in <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L288-L313|https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L2[…]313>  which is called from  <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L402-L421|https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]421>   which in turn is called from <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L402-L421|https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]421>  to get the list of all names
Now this stuff rapidly hit my ignorance of typescript.  But it seems like we would need to get the listing thing (which I might have done correctly already) with the regex (which might also be correct)?  for support there.

But what I don't understand there is what happens next?  How does it fill in the other details, etc. ?  I think it is in <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L423-L493|https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]493>  but I don't understand that code or how it could be cross-language?  The <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L438-L443|https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]443>  end look like they might need to be Julia specific?

I think I agree with this, though a lot is out of our hands.   Your medium-term sure sounds great, but maybe there is some low hanging fruit.

As far as I understand the current situation:
The inspector thing is just something that is setup through the json for the jupyter extension... or at least that is the hope.  It then replaces the current
They think it may have used to work, but after julia stopped supporting
whos
it needed to be fixed.  I think my solution is a good start already in
and might be enough to go talk to them
I think that the typescript code that uses this stuff might be in
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L2[…]313
which is called from
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]421
which in turn is called from
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]421
to get the list of all names

Now this stuff rapidly hit my ignorance of typescript.  But it seems like we would need to get the listing thing (which I might have done correctly already) with the regex (which might also be correct)?  for support there.

But what I don't understand there is what happens next?  How does it fill in the other details, etc. ?  I think it is in
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]493

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/69a2fb578b5b1cd1ae836934885b24e87cbd2e39/src/client/datascience/jupyter/kernelVariables.ts#L4[…]443
end look like they might need to be Julia specific?

messages.text:
The only thing sI will say about the debugger <@U68UUUFPS> is that I have no doubt it will be the trickiest thing to get right.  But I have also yet to sucessfuly use the julia debugger a single time.  I don't mean this as a gripe, it is just a reality for me at least.... anything that is small enough to have usable performance when starting the debugger is something so small that I have never needed a debugger for that tiny of a function.  Maybe there is some sequence of tricks and settings and structure that would work for nontrivial scripts, but I have yet to find it.

So while in principle I think invseting a whole bunch in the jupyter debugger integration (either in jupyterlab or in vscode) is great, it may not be any more usable than the current debugger...

elements.text: The only thing sI will say about the debugger

is that I have no doubt it will be the trickiest thing to get right.  But I have also yet to sucessfuly use the julia debugger a single time.  I don't mean this as a gripe, it is just a reality for me at least.... anything that is small enough to have usable performance when starting the debugger is something so small that I have never needed a debugger for that tiny of a function.  Maybe there is some sequence of tricks and settings and structure that would work for nontrivial scripts, but I have yet to find it.

So while in principle I think invseting a whole bunch in the jupyter debugger integration (either in jupyterlab or in vscode) is great, it may not be any more usable than the current debugger...

messages.text: Hi All. just started using the extension! so awesome. But `@edit` isn’t working for me because `ENV["JULIA_EDITOR"]` is incorrect. How do i set that?

@edit
isn’t working for me because

is incorrect. How do i set that?

messages.text: Could it be disabled that a single newline is printed whenever a code block is executed, even if it doesn't return anything? It looks weird if the repl becomes this large empty area after a while

print("foo")
, because that will be inivisble

messages.text: checking whether user code wrote something (and whether that something was terminated with a linebreak) works, kinda, but isn't particularly robust

elements.text: checking whether user code wrote something (and whether that something was terminated with a linebreak) works, kinda, but isn't particularly robust

messages.text: So the linebreak comes from the extension in order to ensure that separate code blocks get fresh lines to start with? Would it hurt to remove that as most things that print add linebreaks anyway? I think I find the unnecessary linebreak in the default case more annoying than the occasional print statement without one

elements.text: So the linebreak comes from the extension in order to ensure that separate code blocks get fresh lines to start with? Would it hurt to remove that as most things that print add linebreaks anyway? I think I find the unnecessary linebreak in the default case more annoying than the occasional print statement without one

messages.text: No, the linebreak is printed so the new `julia>` prompt doesn't overwrite your code's output

elements.text: No, the linebreak is printed so the new
julia>
prompt doesn't overwrite your code's output

messages.text: Hello, is there some nice way of rendering LaTeXStrings in vscode? Alternatively rendering some image format created from such a LaTeXString? I don't mind some coding.

elements.text: Hello, is there some nice way of rendering LaTeXStrings in vscode? Alternatively rendering some image format created from such a LaTeXString? I don't mind some coding.

messages.text: You can render whatever you want in the plotpane, so yes. Inline results and other UI elements we control don't support anything but markdown.

elements.text: You can render whatever you want in the plotpane, so yes. Inline results and other UI elements we control don't support anything but markdown.

messages.text: aah

messages.text: we support these mime types: <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/blob/0b29e900b4fb8a4d93b07d4af8a8fafa7382a587/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/display.jl#L65-L78>

elements.text: we support these mime types:

messages.text:
```const DISPLAYABLE_MIMES = [
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v2+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v5+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.plotly.v1+json",
    "juliavscode/html",
    # "text/html",
    "image/svg+xml",
    "image/png",
    "image/gif"
]```

elements.text:
const DISPLAYABLE_MIMES = [
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.vegalite.v2+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v5+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v4+json",
    "application/vnd.vega.v3+json",
    "application/vnd.plotly.v1+json",
    "juliavscode/html",
    # "text/html",
    "image/svg+xml",
    "image/png",
    "image/gif"
]

messages.text:
I can't execute some commands in VSCode using `run` :
```shell> kma
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]

julia> run(`kma`)
ERROR: IOError: could not spawn `kma`: no such file or directory (ENOENT)```
Versus in a normal terminal
```shell> kma
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]

julia> run(`kma`)
# KMA enables alignment towards databases, using two k-mer mapping steps and one alignment step.
[ ... ]```

julia> run(`kma`)

[ ... ]

messages.text: <@U6BNE7LTZ> BTW, I confirmed that there is no syntax highlighting in the julia notebooks in vscode on my machine.  My bet is that you had manually tried to move those files around sometime and forgot that you had done it.  So, basically, without a resolution to <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/105229>  I don't think we can have syntax highlightin.

messages.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

elements.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

messages.text: Scrolling up, I see there was a similar question yesterday. Oops. My problem is a little weirder / more specific anyway. I’m using nested projects to provide test dependencies, which I think is supposed to be the standard way now? When I run the test command it is seemingly only picking up the Project.toml in my test directory instead of recursing through the root. My “Julia env” in the bottom bar is showing the root, so I’m not sure what is causing this or how to resolve it.

root.text: Super basic question, but I’m not super familiar with vscode or the extension. How do I test a package I’m developing? I found there is a test task in the command palette, but when I run it it says my package’s name couldn’t be resolved.

Scrolling up, I see there was a similar question yesterday. Oops. My problem is a little weirder / more specific anyway. I’m using nested projects to provide test dependencies, which I think is supposed to be the standard way now? When I run the test command it is seemingly only picking up the Project.toml in my test directory instead of recursing through the root. My “Julia env” in the bottom bar is showing the root, so I’m not sure what is causing this or how to resolve it.

messages.text: I have a weird issue where, if I open a Julia REPL from within VSCode, figures are not displayed. They do show up if I just use a regular REPL. I'm using PyPlot to make figures. I tried it with multiple versions of Julia on macOS. I'm running version 1.0.10 of the VSCode Julia extension. In the VSCode settings I have the "Use Plot Pane" setting set to false. Anyone has an idea how I could fix this?

elements.text: I have a weird issue where, if I open a Julia REPL from within VSCode, figures are not displayed. They do show up if I just use a regular REPL. I'm using PyPlot to make figures. I tried it with multiple versions of Julia on macOS. I'm running version 1.0.10 of the VSCode Julia extension. In the VSCode settings I have the "Use Plot Pane" setting set to false. Anyone has an idea how I could fix this?

messages.text: I think that's a bug in the extension. Will take a look

elements.text: I think that's a bug in the extension. Will take a look

messages.text: Will be fixed with <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/1856>. In the meantime you can call `pygui(true)` to force the PyPlot figures to show up.

elements.text: Will be fixed with
. In the meantime you can call
pygui(true)
to force the PyPlot figures to show up.

messages.text: That works indeed :slightly_smiling_face: Much appreciated.

elements.text: That works indeed
Much appreciated.

messages.text: How can I work with Weave.jl and `.jmd` Julia markdown files inside of VSCode? <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode#features|Integrated support is mentioned>, but the <https://www.julia-vscode.org/docs/stable/userguide/weave/|docs are empty>. Shortcuts like Shift+Enter don’t work.

messages.text: Do you all use Markdown All in One and Markdown Preview Enhanced together? I find loading both slow down vs code substantially.  I'm not exactly sure why I have both installed, because both packages seem to overlap quite a bit.
